newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israelis wound 20 Palestinians in Hebron clashes.
newsitem.headline: Israelis wound 20 Palestinians in Hebron clashes.

text.p: Israeli soldiers firing rubber bullets wounded about 20 Palestinians on Friday during a seventh day of street battles with Arab demonstrators in the divided West Bank town of Hebron, witnesses said.
One 18-year-old Palestinian youth was shot and seriously wounded in the head and doctors at al-Ahli hospital struggled to save his life, officials said.
Witnesses said demonstrators hurled hundreds of fire bombs at Israeli troops, setting ablaze a room where soldiers were sheltering but none was hurt. Firefighters put out the flames.
The witnesses said a small crowd of about 100 Arab stone-throwers ignited the clashes. The group soon swelled to hundreds of youths.

One witness said a soldier was hurt when a stun grenade he was trying to throw at demonstrators fell near him. They said other soldiers took him to one of several Jewish settler enclaves in the Israeli-controlled part of the town.
Youths taunted soldiers by running with a blue-and-white Israeli flag they had set on fire. They also torched two American flags, witnesses said.

The Hebron clashes began last Saturday after a U.S. congressional vote demanding that President Bill Clinton recognise Arab East Jerusalem, viewed by Palestinians as the capital of their future state, as part of Israel's capiptal.
More than 100 Palestinians have been shot and wounded by rubber bullets in six days of violence along the dividing line. Several Israeli soldiers have been hurt.
Palestinians said that unlike on previous days, when most of the stone-throwers were children aged between 10 and 15, many of the demonstrators on Friday were adults.

The clashes underscored tensions over a three-month impasse in Israeli-Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) peace moves and Israel's expansion of Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, including Arab East Jerusalem.

Israel handed over 80 percent of Hebron, the southernmost West Bank city, to Palestinian self-rule in January but kept troops behind to guard some 400 Jewish settlers living or studying in the remaining 20 percent.

The first casualty on Friday was a young man who stood next to a demonstrator concealing his face with a chequered black and white Arab headdress and wore the red, white, black and green Palestinian national colours, witnesses said.
They said one soldier aimed at the demonstrator but hit the person standing next to him in the leg.
